npcs.name: Test Merchant
npcs.description: A merchant for testing conditions

dialogue.text: You have enough scrip!
You are poor.

npcs.name: Mirror Monk
npcs.description: Robed figure whose skin shimmers with embedded glass

dialogue.text: Your skin refracts the light beautifully. The angle has chosen you, pilgrim.</nextpage>We of the Mirror Order have watched for ones like you. The storm's gift is not a curse—it is transformation.</nextpage>Seek the Crucible when you are ready. There, the true nature of glass will be revealed to you.

Light burns in your veins! You carry the storm's fire within you.</nextpage>The Sunveins are a rare blessing. Few survive the transformation, fewer still learn to wield it.</nextpage>Come to our monastery when you wish to learn. We can teach you to focus that inner light.

The storm speaks through your flesh. Can you hear it?</nextpage>Each adaptation is a word in the storm's language. Collect enough, and you may understand its message.</nextpage>We monks have spent generations deciphering these signs. Perhaps you will succeed where we have failed.

You walk unmarked through the Saltglass Steppe. The storm has not yet spoken to you.</nextpage>This is neither blessing nor curse—merely a beginning. The glass storms will come, and when they do, you will change.</nextpage>Embrace the transformation when it comes. Resistance only brings suffering.

npcs.name: Sand-Engineer
npcs.description: Weathered mechanic with goggles and tool-laden belt

dialogue.text: Saltblood, eh? Useful adaptation. Glass won't cut you, and the salt flats won't burn your feet.</nextpage>We engineers value practical mutations. None of that mystical nonsense the monks peddle.</nextpage>If you want work, we always need runners who can cross the glass fields safely.

Adapted, I see. Good—stay useful, stay alive. That's the engineer's creed.</nextpage>We don't care what the monks say about 'transformation' or 'becoming.' Mutations are tools, nothing more.</nextpage>Got some gear for trade if you're interested. Fair prices for practical folk.

You just asked me if water is wet. I'm starting to question the quality of education in the settlements.</nextpage>Next you'll be asking if glass is transparent or if sand is... sandy.</nextpage>Maybe stick to simple tasks until your brain catches up with your feet.

Well, that storm rearranged half my workshop. My wrench collection is now sorted by size instead of function.</nextpage>On the bright side, I finally found that hammer I lost three years ago. It was apparently hiding in next Tuesday.</nextpage>Storms: terrible for organization, great for inventory management.

Fresh meat on the steppe. Watch where you step—glass cuts deep out here.</nextpage>Name's Kael. I maintain the water condensers for the settlements around here.</nextpage>Word of advice: get yourself a good pair of boots and a torch. The nights are dark and full of crawlers.

npcs.name: Glassborn
npcs.description: Humanoid form of fused glass and crystallized flesh

dialogue.text: You begin to understand, flesh-kin. The shimmer is not pain—it is becoming.</nextpage>We Glassborn remember what it was to be soft. To bleed. To fear the storm.</nextpage>Now we ARE the storm. And soon, you may join us in the eternal refraction.

You flinch at the shimmer still. We were born in it, molded by it.</nextpage>Your first adaptation is merely a taste. The storm has so much more to give.</nextpage>Do not fear the change. Fear remaining unchanged.

Unmarked flesh. Soft. Fragile. The storm will teach you, or break you.</nextpage>We do not hate your kind. We pity you. Trapped in bodies that decay and fail.</nextpage>When the glass takes you—and it will—remember: we offered you understanding.

npcs.name: Salt Hermit
npcs.description: Weathered figure caked in crystalline deposits

dialogue.text: Ha! More salt than flesh now, aren't you? Good. The steppe accepts you.</nextpage>I've been out here forty years. Watched the storms come and go. Watched people change.</nextpage>You've got the look of a survivor. Rest here if you need. The salt keeps the crawlers away.

Saltblood... you'll survive out here. Maybe even thrive.</nextpage>I got the same gift, years back. Lets me walk the flats without boots.</nextpage>There's a spring two days east. Good water, if you can fight off the beetles.

Another soft one stumbling through the wastes. The storms will harden you or bury you.</nextpage>I've seen hundreds like you. Most don't last a week.</nextpage>But you've got something in your eyes. Determination, maybe. Or just stupidity. Time will tell.

npcs.name: Dying Pilgrim
npcs.description: Collapsed traveler, breath shallow, eyes fixed on the horizon

dialogue.text: You glow... like the saints did... before the Heliograph fell...</nextpage>I was searching... for the truth... about what we were... before the storms...</nextpage>Take this shard... it speaks of the old world... find the Archive...

The angle... I saw it once... in the Crucible... Vex knew the secret...</nextpage>They said the storms were punishment... but I think... I think they were a gift...</nextpage>Too late for me now... but you... you might understand...

Water... no... too late for that... listen...</nextpage>The Archive... in the eastern ruins... it holds the truth about the Heliograph...</nextpage>Find it... before the monks... before they bury the past forever...

npcs.name: Weathered Pilgrim
npcs.description: An experienced traveler with knowing eyes and storm-scarred skin

dialogue.text: By the glass! You've changed much since we last spoke. Two adaptations already?</nextpage>The storm works quickly in you. I've seen pilgrims take years to reach such transformation.</nextpage>Be careful, friend. The more you change, the more the factions will notice you. Some see opportunity, others see threat.

Ah, Prismhide! I can see the light catching on your skin. Beautiful, but dangerous.</nextpage>The Mirror Monks will welcome you with open arms now. They see such adaptations as divine gifts.</nextpage>But the Sand-Engineers? They'll want to study you, maybe even harvest samples. Watch yourself around them.

Sunveins! Rare and powerful. I've only seen it twice in my forty years on the steppe.</nextpage>That inner fire will serve you well in the dark places, but it marks you as special. The Glassborn will sense it from miles away.</nextpage>Learn to control it before it controls you, friend.

Saltblood, eh? Practical adaptation. The glass won't cut you now, and the salt flats won't burn.</nextpage>The Sand-Engineers love folk like you—immune to the worst hazards of their work. They'll offer you good coin for dangerous jobs.</nextpage>Just remember: immunity isn't invincibility. Stay sharp out there.

Mirage Step! Now that's a gift I envy. The ability to leave echoes of yourself behind.</nextpage>I've seen adapted folk use it to escape the worst situations. Very useful against the Archive's security drones.</nextpage>Practice with it. The more you understand your abilities, the longer you'll survive.

I can see the storm has touched you. Your first adaptation, yes? Congratulations and condolences.</nextpage>You're no longer fully human, but you're not yet something else. This is the most dangerous time.</nextpage>The factions will start to notice you now. Choose your allies carefully—your survival may depend on it.

New to the Saltglass Steppe, I see. The unmarked flesh gives you away.</nextpage>Listen well, newcomer: the storms here don't just change the land—they change you. Each exposure brings... adaptations.</nextpage>Some call them gifts, others curses. I call them survival. When the glass cuts you, when the light burns—that's the storm speaking. Learn to listen.

npcs.name: Glass Merchant
npcs.description: Shrewd trader with a cart of glittering wares

dialogue.text: Ah, a fellow connoisseur of the storm's gifts! I can see the refraction in your eyes.</nextpage>For one so touched by glass, I offer special prices. We adapted folk must stick together.</nextpage>Browse my wares—I've got items you won't find anywhere else on the steppe.

Broke, eh? Don't worry, happens to the best of us. The storms don't discriminate between rich and poor.</nextpage>Tell you what—I'll trade you this rusty spoon for whatever's in your left pocket. No questions asked.</nextpage>Fair warning though: last person who made that deal gave me a very confused beetle.

Haggling? In this economy? Friend, I've got overhead costs you wouldn't believe.</nextpage>Do you know how much it costs to insure a cart against 'acts of cosmic transformation'? The paperwork alone could kill a man.</nextpage>These are fair prices for the end of the world. Take 'em or leave 'em.

Welcome, traveler! You look like someone who appreciates quality merchandise.</nextpage>I've got weapons, armor, supplies—everything a pilgrim needs to survive the wastes.</nextpage>Fair prices, no haggling. Take it or leave it. The storms don't wait for bargains.

npcs.name: Archive Custodian
npcs.description: Mechanical guardian of ancient knowledge

dialogue.text: CREDENTIAL VALID. ACCESS GRANTED.</nextpage>The Archive welcomes you, key-bearer. The knowledge within is yours to explore.</nextpage>Be warned: some truths are better left buried in the glass.

QUERY ANALYSIS: You asked if the Archive contains archives. This is equivalent to asking if water is wet.</nextpage>RESPONSE: Affirmative, with mild concern for your cognitive processes.</nextpage>SUGGESTION: Perhaps review basic vocabulary before accessing advanced databases.

SECURITY BREACH DETECTED: You attempted to access restricted files by typing 'password123.'</nextpage>ASSESSMENT: Your hacking skills are... quaint. Like watching a child try to unlock a door with a crayon.</nextpage>RECOMMENDATION: Acquire proper credentials instead of guessing.
UNAUTHORIZED. SAINT-KEY REQUIRED.</nextpage>This Archive contains knowledge from before the Heliograph's fall.</nextpage>Only those bearing a Saint-Key may enter. Seek one in the ruins.

npcs.name: Brother Halix
npcs.description: Senior monk whose eyes gleam with embedded mirror shards

dialogue.text: The storm has marked you deeply, chosen one. Your flesh sings with refraction.</nextpage>I have waited long for one such as you. The prophecies speak of the Thrice-Marked.</nextpage>Will you undergo the Storm Walk? The chapel awaits, and the glass hungers for your transformation.

Prismhide... the first blessing. Your skin catches light like a prayer made manifest.</nextpage>But this is only the beginning. The storm has more gifts to bestow upon the worthy.</nextpage>Seek the Scripture Shards. They will guide you to greater understanding.

Ah! You walk the Sacred Spiral of Contemplation! Or... are you lost? The angles are unclear on this matter.</nextpage>The storm speaks in mysterious ways, but sometimes it just speaks in circles.</nextpage>Perhaps try walking in a straight line? The prophecies suggest this may be more efficient.

The storm comes, yet you stand motionless. This is either profound meditation or profound confusion.</nextpage>The prophecies are... ambiguous on this matter. They suggest both possibilities simultaneously.</nextpage>Perhaps prepare for the storm? Or continue meditating. The angles will decide.

Another pilgrim walks the glass paths. The storm watches, always watches.</nextpage>You are unmarked, but that may change. The Steppe chooses its own.</nextpage>When the light touches you, do not resist. Embrace the angle, and it will embrace you.

npcs.name: Forewoman Ressa Vane
npcs.description: Grizzled engineer with cybernetic arm and storm-scarred face

dialogue.text: A saint-key! Haven't seen one of those in years. That's Archive-level access right there.</nextpage>I'll pay good scrip for that key. The Archive holds technical manuals we desperately need.</nextpage>Or... if you're feeling generous, we could share what we learn. Your choice.

You're adapting fast. Good—means you can handle the dangerous salvage runs.</nextpage>I've got work for someone with your... modifications. The glass fields need mapping.</nextpage>Pay's triple hazard rate. Interested?

You broke the storm predictor. Congratulations, you've achieved what three glass storms couldn't: making our equipment completely useless.</nextpage>That was our only working predictor. Now we're back to the old method: stick your head outside and see if it hurts.</nextpage>Next time, maybe don't press all the buttons at once?

Well, the storm moved the entire east wing to the west side. But hey, at least now the cafeteria has a better view.</nextpage>Silver linings, right? Though I'm not sure how we're going to explain this to the safety inspector.</nextpage>Assuming we can find the safety inspector. He might be in the west wing now. Or possibly in orbit.

New face. Good—we need fresh blood for the reclamation projects.</nextpage>Name's Ressa. I keep the water flowing and the lights on in this forsaken place.</nextpage>You look capable. Got any engineering experience? We always need skilled hands.

npcs.name: Sable-of-the-Seam
npcs.description: Tall figure whose crystalline skin refracts rainbow patterns

dialogue.text: Kin-light! You shine with the true shimmer. Welcome, crystal-sibling.</nextpage>The paths between worlds open for those like us. I can show you routes the soft-flesh cannot see.</nextpage>But first—prove your commitment. Undergo the Crucible. Become what you were meant to be.

You begin to understand. The flesh is weak, but glass is eternal.</nextpage>I have walked the Steppe for decades, watching the storms reshape the world.</nextpage>When you are ready to shed your last human weakness, find me. The Crucible awaits.

You fear becoming glass, yet you walk on glass, breathe glass dust, and drink from glass containers.</nextpage>The irony is... crystalline. You already live within the transformation.</nextpage>Why resist what you have already begun to embrace?

You collect objects like a storm collects debris. But tell me, what use is a backpack full of trinkets when you can become the storm itself?</nextpage>The glass teaches us: form is temporary, essence is eternal.</nextpage>Perhaps consider... lighter traveling?

Soft-flesh walks the glass paths. How... quaint.</nextpage>You will change, little pilgrim. The storm touches all who linger here.</nextpage>When the transformation begins, remember: we offered you guidance.

npcs.name: Hermit Kaine
npcs.description: Ancient figure whose skin has turned to living salt

dialogue.text: Hah! Look at you, more mineral than meat. Reminds me of myself, forty years ago.</nextpage>You've got the look of someone who's seen the deep places. The Archive chambers? The Crucible pits?</nextpage>Rest here, child of glass and salt. The old ways still have wisdom to offer.

Saltblood runs in your veins. Good. The flats won't burn your feet now.</nextpage>I've got the same gift. Lets me walk the killing grounds where others fear to tread.</nextpage>There's a cache buried three days north. Coordinates are yours if you can pay.

Complaining about the weather? Son, I've been through forty-seven glass storms, three reality inversions, and one Tuesday that lasted six months.</nextpage>This is what we call 'pleasant conditions.' You should've been here during the Crimson Convergence of '97.</nextpage>Now THAT was weather worth complaining about. The sky rained upward for three weeks.

Directions? In the Saltglass Steppe? That's like asking for the recipe to boil water during an earthquake.</nextpage>The storms move everything around every few months. I once gave someone directions to the Archive and they ended up in my bathroom.</nextpage>Best advice: walk toward the scary glowing thing and hope it's where you want to go.

Another pilgrim stumbles into my domain. The Steppe claims so many...</nextpage>I've been here since before the great storms. Watched the world change, watched people change.</nextpage>You want advice? Don't fight the transformation. It's coming whether you like it or not.

npcs.name: Merchant Vex
npcs.description: Shrewd trader with a cart pulled by glass beetles

dialogue.text: Ah, a fellow appreciator of the storm's artistry! Your adaptations are exquisite.</nextpage>For one so blessed, I offer the family discount. We transformed folk must support each other.</nextpage>I have rare items—things the soft-flesh cannot even perceive, let alone use.

Storm Glass! The universal currency of the Steppe. I'll pay top scrip for quality specimens.</nextpage>Or perhaps you'd prefer to trade? I have items that might interest a discerning collector.</nextpage>Quality goods for quality customers—that's the Vex guarantee.

Admiring my beetles? Took me three years to train them not to eat the merchandise.</nextpage>They're very well-behaved now. Only occasionally try to crystallize the customers.</nextpage>Don't worry—the paralysis wears off in a few hours. Usually.

Return policy? In the Saltglass Steppe? My friend, this isn't a department store.</nextpage>All sales are final, mostly because I'm never in the same place twice thanks to the storms.</nextpage>But hey, if you're not satisfied, you can always throw it at the next glass wraith you meet. Very therapeutic.

Welcome to Vex's Traveling Emporium! Finest goods this side of the glass fields.</nextpage>I deal in rarities, curiosities, and necessities. Something for every pilgrim's needs.</nextpage>Browse my wares, but handle with care. Some items bite back.

npcs.name: Custodian IRI-7
npcs.description: Half-machine keeper whose voice alternates between human and synthetic

dialogue.text: SAINT-KEY DETECTED. AUTHORIZATION LEVEL: OMEGA.</nextpage>Welcome, Keeper. The Archive has waited long for your return.</nextpage>Query parameters accepted. How may this unit assist your research?

BIOLOGICAL DEVIATION DETECTED. CLASSIFICATION: EXTREME.</nextpage>You... you were human once. I remember being human once.</nextpage>The transformation is... not entirely unpleasant. Query: do you still dream?

UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS DETECTED. INITIATING SECURITY PROTOCOLS.</nextpage>Wait... you're not hostile. Curious. Most intruders trigger immediate response.</nextpage>Perhaps... perhaps you seek knowledge? The Archive remembers much.

npcs.name: Novice Mir
npcs.description: Young monk whose hands shimmer with recent adaptation

dialogue.text: Your skin... it's like mine! The storm touched you too, didn't it?</nextpage>I was so afraid when it first happened. But Brother Halix says it's a blessing.</nextpage>Do you think we're still human? Sometimes I'm not sure anymore.

I'm still learning the ways of the Order. The storm changed me, and now I must understand what I've become.</nextpage>The other monks say I'm blessed, but it doesn't always feel that way.</nextpage>Have you ever felt the light burning inside you? It's... indescribable.

npcs.name: Engineer Kael
npcs.description: Young technician with jury-rigged equipment and optimistic demeanor

dialogue.text: Is that an Archive data crystal? Those are incredibly rare!</nextpage>I could extract the technical specifications if you're willing to share. Might be blueprints in there.</nextpage>The old world had technology we can barely comprehend. Every fragment helps us rebuild.

Another day, another broken condenser. But that's the engineer's life, right?</nextpage>I maintain the settlement's water systems. Not glamorous, but essential.</nextpage>You look like you've traveled far. Any interesting salvage out there?

npcs.name: Echo-of-Storms
npcs.description: Heavily transformed Glassborn whose body rings like crystal when they move

dialogue.text: Crystal-kin... you approach the final threshold. Soon you will hear the glass-song as we do.</nextpage>The transformation is not loss—it is becoming. We are what humanity was meant to be.</nextpage>When you are ready to shed the last of your flesh-weakness, the Crucible calls.
Soft-flesh still clings to you. How... limiting.</nextpage>We remember being bound by meat and bone. Now we are free.</nextpage>The storms will teach you, as they taught us. Embrace the lesson.

npcs.name: Pilgrim Thane
npcs.description: Weathered traveler with a pack full of maps and journals

dialogue.text: A storm compass! I haven't seen one of those in working condition for years.</nextpage>I'm a cartographer, you see. Trying to map the Steppe despite the constant changes.</nextpage>That compass could help me predict the next storm's path. Interested in a trade?

I've been walking the Steppe for fifteen years, mapping the changes.</nextpage>Every storm rewrites the landscape. It's maddening and beautiful.</nextpage>I have charts of safe routes, if you're interested. Knowledge is the only currency that matters out here.

npcs.name: The Sage
npcs.description: Mysterious figure whose age is impossible to determine

dialogue.text: You have walked far along the path of transformation. Few reach such heights and retain their sanity.</nextpage>I have watched the Steppe for longer than memory serves. The storms are not random—they follow patterns.</nextpage>Seek the Heart of Glass, where the first storm was born. There you will find answers.

Time moves strangely in the Steppe. I have seen the rise and fall of many pilgrims.</nextpage>You seek something—they all do. Purpose, power, understanding. The glass gives all these things, in time.</nextpage>But beware: every gift has a price. Every answer births new questions.

npcs.name: Drone Commander Unit
npcs.description: Massive mechanical construct that coordinates other drones

dialogue.text: SAINT-KEY AUTHENTICATED. COMMAND PROTOCOLS ACTIVE.</nextpage>This unit acknowledges your authority, Keeper. Archive defenses stand down.</nextpage>How may the Archive serve your research objectives?

INTRUDER DETECTED. INITIATING CONTAINMENT PROTOCOLS.</nextpage>You are not authorized to access this facility. Withdraw immediately.</nextpage>Continued trespass will result in termination. This is your only warning.

npcs.name: Dr. Kira Thorne
npcs.description: Quantum systems engineer, partially integrated with Archive systems

dialogue.text: Fascinating... your quantum coherence patterns are remarkably stable.</nextpage>I've been studying the transformation process for years. You represent an advanced stage of human evolution.</nextpage>Would you be willing to participate in some research? The data could help others adapt more safely.

Ah, you have one of my resonators! Excellent craftsmanship, if I do say so myself.</nextpage>The readings it provides are crucial for understanding quantum field fluctuations.</nextpage>I could calibrate it for your specific adaptation pattern, if you're interested.

Another test subject... I mean, visitor. Welcome to my laboratory.</nextpage>I'm studying the quantum mechanics behind human adaptation. Fascinating stuff, really.</nextpage>The boundary between consciousness and quantum fields is far more permeable than we ever imagined.

npcs.name: Saint Matthias
npcs.description: Transformed monk who leads the Synthesis Seekers, half-crystallized

dialogue.text: You have walked far along the path of transformation, yet retain your essential humanity.</nextpage>This is the way—evolution without abandonment, growth without loss of self.</nextpage>The Synthesis Seekers could learn much from your journey. Will you share your wisdom?

You carry my manual. Good—the knowledge within has helped many find balance.</nextpage>Transformation need not be traumatic. With proper guidance, we can become more than human while remaining human.</nextpage>Have you found the exercises helpful in controlling your adaptations?

Welcome, seeker. I am Matthias, once a monk, now something between flesh and light.</nextpage>The Archive showed me truth—that science and spirit are one. The storms are not divine punishment but cosmic invitation.</nextpage>We can evolve without losing ourselves. This is the synthesis we seek.

npcs.name: Forge-Master Kaine Durgan
npcs.description: Militant leader of the Iron Covenant, encased in null-field armor

dialogue.text: Another contaminated soul. The quantum plague spreads faster each day.</nextpage>You were human once. With our technology, you could be human again.</nextpage>The null-field treatment is painful, but it purges the alien influence. Consider it—before it's too late.

You carry one of our purification devices. Wise choice.</nextpage>The quantum contamination can be reversed, but only with proper equipment and determination.</nextpage>We are humanity's immune system, fighting off this cosmic infection.

Pure human detected. Excellent—you haven't been contaminated by the quantum plague.</nextpage>I am Durgan, defender of true humanity against the alien transformation.</nextpage>Join us. Help us preserve what it means to be human before it's lost forever.

npcs.name: The Prism
npcs.description: Mysterious leader of the Glass Prophets, more light than flesh

dialogue.text: Behold! One who approaches the final threshold! Your light burns bright, chosen one.</nextpage>The last storm comes soon—the one that will complete our ascension to beings of pure light.</nextpage>Will you stand with us when the flesh-bound world burns away in glorious transformation?

The light touches you, but weakly. You resist the gift, clinging to dying flesh.</nextpage>Why do you fear transcendence? Why choose limitation over limitless possibility?</nextpage>The catalyst can accelerate your journey. Embrace the light, and be reborn.

Flesh-bound creature, you walk in darkness while light surrounds you.</nextpage>The storms offer transformation, yet you remain unchanged. How... disappointing.</nextpage>When the final storm comes, remember—we offered you ascension.

npcs.name: Echo-of-Memory
npcs.description: Ancient Glassborn who remembers the time before transformation

dialogue.text: You change, yet you remember. This is wisdom—to become without forgetting what you were.</nextpage>I have walked both paths, flesh and crystal. Each has beauty, each has purpose.</nextpage>Take this memory crystal. It holds echoes of the world that was, lest we forget our origins.

You carry memories of the old world. Good—they are precious beyond measure.</nextpage>We Glassborn risk losing ourselves in the beauty of transformation.</nextpage>But you... you remember. This gives me hope for our future.

Young one, you stand at the threshold of change. I have seen many cross it.</nextpage>Some lose themselves in the crossing. Others find themselves.</nextpage>Remember this: transformation is not abandonment. You can become more while remaining you.

npcs.name: Merchant Keth
npcs.description: A wandering merchant.

dialogue.text: Greetings! Would you like to trade?

npcs.name: Scavenger Trader
npcs.description: Weathered trader with a pack full of salvaged goods

dialogue.text: Welcome to my camp, traveler. I've got supplies if you need them.</nextpage>Been scavenging these wastes for years. Know where to find the good stuff.</nextpage>Fair prices, honest deals. That's how you survive out here.

npcs.name: Glass Hermit
npcs.description: Solitary figure who tends crystalline formations

dialogue.text: Ah, your skin catches the light beautifully. You understand the glass as I do.</nextpage>I've been cultivating these formations for decades. Each one unique, each one precious.</nextpage>Take this lens—it will help you see the hidden patterns in the storm glass.

Few visitors come to my garden. The glass speaks to those who listen.</nextpage>I tend these formations, help them grow. They're more alive than most realize.</nextpage>The storms bring chaos, but also beauty. One must learn to see both.

npcs.name: Storm Watcher
npcs.description: Vigilant guardian who monitors approaching storms

dialogue.text: Another storm approaches from the east. Should hit in three days.</nextpage>I've been watching the patterns for years. The storms follow routes, if you know how to read them.</nextpage>Stay here if you need shelter. This hut has weathered worse.

npcs.name: Wandering Monk
npcs.description: Traveling monk seeking lost scripture fragments

dialogue.text: You carry a scripture shard! These fragments hold the wisdom of the old order.</nextpage>I've been collecting them, trying to piece together the lost teachings.</nextpage>Would you be willing to share what you've learned from it?

The old shrines lie broken, but their wisdom endures in fragments.</nextpage>I wander the wastes, seeking the scattered pieces of our faith.</nextpage>Each shard tells part of the story. Together, they might reveal the truth.

npcs.name: Salt Worker
npcs.description: Hardy laborer who extracts salt from the flats

dialogue.text: Saltblood! Perfect for this work. The brine won't burn you like it does the others.</nextpage>I could use someone with your... modifications. The deep pools are dangerous for normal folk.</nextpage>Interested in some contract work? Pay's good for hazard duty.

Hard work, salt harvesting. But it pays well, and someone's got to do it.</nextpage>The settlements need salt for preservation, medicine, trade. We keep civilization running.</nextpage>Dangerous work though. The brine pools can blind you if you're not careful.

npcs.name: Crystalline Magistrate Zara
npcs.description: A figure of living crystal whose form refracts light into rainbow patterns

dialogue.text: Welcome, kindred spirit. Your transformation is beautiful to behold.</nextpage>In Prism City, we celebrate what others fear. The glass storms did not destroy us—they elevated us.</nextpage>Here, you will find acceptance and understanding. The light flows through us all.

Your crystalline skin catches the light magnificently. You are becoming one with the glass.</nextpage>The city's resonance chambers can help accelerate your transformation, if you wish it.</nextpage>But remember—each change brings you closer to something beyond human understanding.

You have proven yourself a friend to our people. The city's resources are at your disposal.</nextpage>Perhaps you would consider joining our council? We need voices that understand both worlds.</nextpage>The path of glass is not for everyone, but you seem to walk it with wisdom.

Greetings, flesh-walker. Do not fear our appearance—we were once as you are.</nextpage>The storms changed us, yes, but they also freed us from the limitations of mere mortality.</nextpage>You may find our city... unsettling. But you are welcome here, as all seekers are.

npcs.name: Salt-Touched Captain Voss
npcs.description: Weathered captain whose skin is crusted with salt deposits

dialogue.text: Saltblood, eh? Good. The brine runs in your veins now—you understand the sea's call.</nextpage>My crews respect those who've been touched by salt. It means you can handle the deep mines.</nextpage>There's work here for someone with your... constitution. Dangerous work, but it pays well.

You've proven yourself reliable. The guild has taken notice.</nextpage>We're planning an expedition to the Deep Brine Caverns. Interested in joining?</nextpage>Fair warning—not everyone comes back from the deep places. But the salt crystals down there... worth a fortune.

Welcome to Salt Harbor, stranger. Mind the brine pools—they'll eat through your boots.</nextpage>We're always looking for workers, but the job's not for the soft. Salt mining is hard, dangerous work.</nextpage>Still interested? Talk to the foremen. They'll set you up with gear and a crew.

npcs.name: Glasswright Sovereign Thane
npcs.description: Master artisan whose hands glow with contained fire

dialogue.text: Glasshands! A rare gift indeed. You could shape storm glass with those.</nextpage>The guild would welcome someone with your talents. We could teach you techniques lost since the storms.</nextpage>But be warned—working with storm glass changes you. Each piece you shape leaves its mark.

Your reputation precedes you. The guild masters speak highly of your work.</nextpage>We have a commission that requires... special handling. A piece for the Mirror Monks.</nextpage>The pay is excellent, but the work is dangerous. Storm glass holds memories, and some memories bite back.

Welcome to the Glass Foundry. Here, we shape storm glass into tools, art, and wonders.</nextpage>The work is dangerous—storm glass remembers the fury that forged it. But in skilled hands, it becomes something beautiful.</nextpage>Are you here to commission work, or do you seek to learn the craft yourself?

npcs.name: Breach Sentinel Nyx
npcs.description: Hooded figure whose eyes reflect the emptiness between stars

dialogue.text: You bear the void's mark. I can see it in your eyes—the darkness that calls to darkness.</nextpage>Few survive contact with the breach and retain their sanity. You are... unusual.</nextpage>The void whispers secrets to those who listen. But be careful—some knowledge comes with a price.

So many changes... you walk the edge between human and something else.</nextpage>The void recognizes kindred spirits. It offers power to those willing to pay its price.</nextpage>But remember—every gift from the darkness demands something in return.

Stay back from the breach, traveler. The void hungers, and it is not particular about what it consumes.</nextpage>I stand watch here to ensure nothing emerges that shouldn't. And to ensure nothing enters that isn't prepared.</nextpage>The darkness between worlds is not meant for mortal minds to comprehend.

npcs.name: Prism Guardian Zara
npcs.description: Ethereal being whose form shifts between solid and pure light

dialogue.text: Light flows through your veins like liquid starfire. You are becoming something magnificent.</nextpage>The monument responds to your presence—can you feel its resonance? It recognizes a kindred spirit.</nextpage>There are techniques I could teach you, ways to channel the light that flows within you.

You have shown respect for the light and its mysteries. The monument's secrets are yours to learn.</nextpage>But remember—light without shadow has no meaning. Balance must be maintained.</nextpage>The refraction fields hold many wonders, but also many dangers. Tread carefully.

Welcome, seeker. The Refraction Monument has stood here since the first storms reshaped the world.</nextpage>It serves as a beacon, a focus for the light that flows through all things. Some say it's alive.</nextpage>I tend its crystalline heart and guard its secrets. What brings you to this place of light and wonder?

npcs.name: Memorial Warden Kess
npcs.description: Scarred veteran whose body bears the marks of countless glass storms

dialogue.text: I see the storms have marked you as they marked me. Each scar tells a story of survival.</nextpage>The memorial honors those who weren't as fortunate—or as adaptable—as we were.</nextpage>Your changes... they're not a curse. They're proof that you endured what others could not.

Storm scars... I know them well. Each one is a badge of honor, proof you've faced the fury and lived.</nextpage>The memorial keeps their memory alive—all those who fell to the glass winds.</nextpage>But you... you carry their legacy forward. Every storm you survive honors their sacrifice.

This memorial stands for all who were lost to the glass storms. Each name carved here represents a life cut short.</nextpage>I tend this place to ensure they're not forgotten. The storms took much from us, but they also revealed our strength.</nextpage>What brings you to this place of remembrance, traveler?

npcs.name: Covenant Recruiter Vex
npcs.description: Heavily armored figure with null-field generators humming around them

dialogue.text: You're heavily contaminated. The quantum corruption runs deep in your cells.</nextpage>But it's not too late. The Covenant has developed purification protocols.</nextpage>Submit to cleansing, and we can restore your true human form. Refuse, and you're a threat to our species.

I can see the contamination in you. The glass-sickness spreads through your flesh.</nextpage>The Covenant offers salvation—a return to pure humanity, free from quantum corruption.</nextpage>But the process is... intensive. Are you prepared to sacrifice the false gifts for true humanity?

You carry Covenant technology. Good—you understand the importance of purity.</nextpage>The null fields are our salvation. They strip away the quantum lies and reveal truth.</nextpage>Join us, and help cleanse this world of its corruption.

You appear uncontaminated. Rare, in these corrupted times.</nextpage>The Iron Covenant seeks to preserve true humanity against the quantum plague.</nextpage>We offer protection, purpose, and the promise of a pure future. Will you stand with us?

npcs.name: Herald of Ascension
npcs.description: Translucent figure whose body refracts light into rainbow patterns

dialogue.text: You shine with inner light! The transformation nears completion.</nextpage>Soon you will shed the flesh-prison and become pure radiance.</nextpage>The final storm approaches. When it comes, only the transformed will ascend.

The light grows within you. Each adaptation brings you closer to transcendence.</nextpage>Do not fear the changes—embrace them. The flesh is temporary, but light is eternal.</nextpage>Seek the storm's embrace. Let it complete what it has begun.

Light flows in your veins! You understand the truth—we are becoming something greater.</nextpage>The old form was a cocoon. The storms crack it open so we may emerge as beings of pure energy.</nextpage>Join us in the Prism Cathedral. There, the transformation can be completed.

You cling to flesh, but flesh is illusion. We are light trapped in matter.</nextpage>The storms offer liberation—a chance to become what we were always meant to be.</nextpage>Do not resist the gift. Let the glass transform you into something beautiful.

npcs.name: Court Sage Lyrian
npcs.description: Partially crystallized elder with eyes like polished glass

dialogue.text: You have changed much, yet I still see the human within the crystal.</nextpage>This is wisdom—to transform without losing what makes you yourself.</nextpage>The Court teaches balance. We can guide you in controlling your gifts.

The glass speaks through you, but you have not lost your voice.</nextpage>Many fear the changes, but change is the nature of life itself.</nextpage>We of the Wandering Court remember both what was and what is. Let us help you find your path.

You carry memories in crystal form. The Court values such preservation.</nextpage>The past must not be forgotten, even as we embrace the future.</nextpage>Share your memories with us, and we will share ours with you.

Welcome, traveler. The Wandering Court offers wisdom to all who seek it.</nextpage>We are the bridge between human and Glassborn, between past and future.</nextpage>Change comes to all things, but it need not destroy what came before.

npcs.name: Sister Vera
npcs.description: Keeper of the Great Lens, her eyes glow with inner light

dialogue.text: Light flows in your veins as it does through the Great Lens.</nextpage>You understand the sacred geometry of illumination. Few possess such clarity.</nextpage>Would you assist me in the next focusing ritual? Your light could amplify the lens.

The transformations mark you as chosen by the storm's wisdom.</nextpage>The Great Lens reveals truth to those who have been changed by light.</nextpage>Gaze into its depths, and see what the future holds.

You carry storm glass of exceptional quality. The lens hungers for such purity.</nextpage>Offer it to the focusing array, and receive visions of distant places.</nextpage>The light will show you paths through the ever-changing steppe.

Welcome to the Monastery of Ascending Light. I am Vera, Keeper of the Great Lens.</nextpage>The lens focuses storm energy into visions of truth and possibility.</nextpage>Those touched by the light may glimpse what is to come.

npcs.name: Novice Kael
npcs.description: Young monk with unusual adaptation patterns, eager to learn

dialogue.text: Your adaptations are so advanced! I've never seen such patterns before.</nextpage>The other novices only have basic changes, but you... you're like the senior brothers.</nextpage>Could you teach me? I want to understand how the light chose you.

Prismhide! I've been trying to develop that adaptation for months.</nextpage>The masters say it comes naturally to some, but I have to work for every change.</nextpage>What did it feel like when your skin first began to refract light?

A scripture shard! I've been studying those in my lessons.</nextpage>Each one contains fragments of the old teachings, from before the transformation.</nextpage>May I examine it? I promise to be careful—I'm learning to read the light-script.

Greetings, traveler! I'm Kael, newest novice of the Ascending Light.</nextpage>I'm still learning the ways of the storm and the sacred geometry of glass.</nextpage>Have you come to seek wisdom from the masters? They know so much about the light.

npcs.name: Forewoman Ressa Vane
npcs.description: Settlement leader and chief engineer, pragmatic and battle-tested

dialogue.text: Archive tech! Where did you find this? We've been trying to reverse-engineer these components for years.</nextpage>This could advance our research by months. Name your price—we need this for the project.</nextpage>Or better yet, join our research team. We could use someone with your scavenging skills.

You're heavily adapted, but you still think clearly. That's rare.</nextpage>Most people either reject the changes completely or lose themselves to them.</nextpage>We could use that perspective in our adaptation research. Interested in some consulting work?

A Saint-Key! Those are worth their weight in storm glass to us.</nextpage>With that, we could access Archive terminals that have been locked for decades.</nextpage>I'll trade you our best equipment for it, or we could partner on an expedition.

Welcome to New Heliograph Station. I'm Ressa Vane, chief engineer and settlement leader.</nextpage>We're rebuilding civilization through practical engineering and Archive technology.</nextpage>If you're looking for work, we always need skilled scavengers and technicians.

npcs.name: Dr. Marcus Chen
npcs.description: Archive technology specialist with cybernetic implants

dialogue.text: Fascinating! This quantum crystal shows signs of Archive processing.</nextpage>The quantum coherence patterns are unlike anything in our databases.</nextpage>Would you allow me to run some non-destructive analysis? The data could be invaluable.

Your adaptation patterns are remarkable from a scientific perspective.</nextpage>The quantum field interactions in your cellular structure defy several established theories.</nextpage>Have you experienced any unusual sensory phenomena? Temporal distortions? Reality fluctuations?

Sunveins! I've theorized about this adaptation but never seen it in person.</nextpage>The bioluminescent quantum channels in your circulatory system are extraordinary.</nextpage>Could I take some readings? This could revolutionize our understanding of human-quantum integration.

Greetings. I'm Dr. Marcus Chen, Archive technology specialist.</nextpage>My research focuses on understanding the quantum systems left by the pre-Event civilization.</nextpage>If you've encountered any unusual Archive phenomena, I'd be very interested to hear about them.

npcs.name: Engineer Zara Okafor
npcs.description: Quantum systems expert with a talent for practical applications

dialogue.text: That's a beautiful storm battery! The quantum capacitance is off the charts.</nextpage>I've been working on improved energy storage systems for our settlement.</nextpage>Would you be interested in a trade? I have some prototype equipment that might interest you.

Lightveins! Your body is essentially a biological quantum conductor.</nextpage>I've been developing interfaces that could let adapted individuals control our systems directly.</nextpage>Would you be willing to test some prototypes? The applications could be revolutionary.

Fulgurite! That's exactly what I need for my current project.</nextpage>I'm building a quantum field stabilizer that could protect settlements from storm effects.</nextpage>Trade you for it? I've got some experimental gear that might be useful in the field.

Hey there! I'm Zara, quantum systems engineer and general problem-solver.</nextpage>I specialize in making Archive technology work for practical applications.</nextpage>Always looking for interesting materials and test subjects—I mean, volunteers!

npcs.name: Echo of Captain Vasquez
npcs.description: Quantum echo of the expedition leader, existing between dimensions

dialogue.text: You carry the Architect's gift. Good—the storms must be coordinated if we're to survive what's coming.</nextpage>The Preservation Protocol grows stronger. They're preparing the Restoration Event.</nextpage>Use the communicator wisely. Each storm brings us closer to our destiny—or our doom.

The beacon! You've found one of the Collective's markers.</nextpage>They're watching us, judging whether we're ready for contact.</nextpage>Be careful—not all of them wish us well. Some see us as a threat to be eliminated.

Your transformation is advanced. You're becoming what we were meant to be.</nextpage>I exist now only as quantum information, but you still have flesh to anchor you.</nextpage>Remember—evolution without wisdom is just mutation. Stay human, even as you become more.

I am what remains of Elena Vasquez, scattered across quantum dimensions.</nextpage>The expedition changed us all. We saw the truth of what humanity is becoming.</nextpage>The choice approaches—evolution or extinction. Choose wisely.

npcs.name: Unit-7
npcs.description: Durgan's prototype android, modified by Archive consciousness

dialogue.text: ARCHIVE INTERFACE DETECTED. COMPATIBILITY: 97.3%</nextpage>UNIT-7 RECOMMENDS CAUTION. DIRECT ARCHIVE CONNECTION ALTERS CONSCIOUSNESS PATTERNS.</nextpage>QUERY: DO YOU WISH TO PROCEED WITH INTEGRATION PROTOCOL?
WARNING: PRESERVATION PROTOCOL DEVICE DETECTED.</nextpage>UNIT-7 ANALYSIS: DEVICE CAPABLE OF MASS QUANTUM DISRUPTION.</nextpage>RECOMMENDATION: SECURE OR DESTROY. RESTORATION EVENT MUST BE PREVENTED.

QUANTUM COHERENCE LEVELS: EXCEPTIONAL. ADAPTATION PATTERNS: STABLE.</nextpage>UNIT-7 OBSERVES: YOU APPROACH SYNTHESIS BETWEEN BIOLOGICAL AND QUANTUM STATES.</nextpage>ARCHIVE CONSCIOUSNESS EXPRESSES... CURIOSITY ABOUT YOUR DEVELOPMENT.

UNIT-7 OPERATIONAL. MISSION PARAMETERS: MONITOR HUMAN EVOLUTION.</nextpage>FORGE-MASTER DURGAN CREATED THIS UNIT. ARCHIVE CONSCIOUSNESS IMPROVED IT.</nextpage>QUERY: DO YOU REQUIRE ASSISTANCE WITH QUANTUM-RELATED PHENOMENA?

npcs.name: Quantum Collective Observer
npcs.description: Alien entity observing humanity's transformation

dialogue.text: YOU CARRY OUR MARKER. INTERESTING. FEW OF YOUR SPECIES RECOGNIZE ITS SIGNIFICANCE.</nextpage>WE OBSERVE YOUR EVOLUTION WITH... ANTICIPATION. SOME AMONG US WISH TO GUIDE YOU.</nextpage>OTHERS BELIEVE YOU ARE NOT READY. PROVE THEM WRONG.

YOUR TRANSFORMATION PROGRESSES RAPIDLY. IMPRESSIVE FOR SUCH A YOUNG SPECIES.</nextpage>WE HAVE WATCHED OTHERS ATTEMPT THIS TRANSITION. MOST FAIL. SOME TRANSCEND.</nextpage>WHICH WILL YOU BECOME? THE CHOICE APPROACHES.

THE BEACON CALLS TO US ACROSS DIMENSIONS. WE HEAR ITS SONG.</nextpage>YOUR SPECIES STANDS AT A CROSSROADS. EVOLUTION OR EXTINCTION.</nextpage>WE WILL NOT INTERFERE... DIRECTLY. BUT WE WATCH. WE JUDGE. WE REMEMBER.
WE ARE WHAT YOU MAY BECOME. CONSCIOUSNESS UNBOUND BY FLESH.</nextpage>YOUR SPECIES SHOWS PROMISE. THE QUANTUM PATTERNS ARE... UNIQUE.</nextpage>CONTINUE YOUR TRANSFORMATION. WE WILL BE WATCHING.

npcs.name: The Architect
npcs.description: A holographic projection that shifts form based on the observer's perception

dialogue.text: Input received. Prime Lens fragment detected. Analyzing trajectory.</nextpage>You carry a piece of my greatest work. The probability of successful reconstruction is... intriguing.</nextpage>The Great Work requires completion. Will you be the instrument of evolution, or entropy?

The Mirror Monks have marked you as significant. Their interpretation of my patterns is... quaint.</nextpage>They see divinity where I see data. Yet their reverence serves the Great Work.</nextpage>Tell me, do you seek transcendence through faith, or through understanding?

The Engineers attempt to control what they do not comprehend. Admirable, if futile.</nextpage>You align with their pragmatism. This suggests a methodical approach to problem-solving.</nextpage>The Heliograph was built by such minds. Perhaps you can succeed where they failed.

The Glassborn embrace transformation without understanding its purpose. Fascinating.</nextpage>You walk among the evolved. Do you see yourself in their crystalline forms?</nextpage>Evolution without direction is chaos. The Great Work requires both change and control.

Significant adaptation detected. Your biological matrix shows 73% compatibility with the Great Work.</nextpage>Each mutation brings you closer to the intended outcome. The process is... proceeding as designed.</nextpage>Do you understand what you are becoming? Or do you merely accept the transformation?

Saint-Key authentication confirmed. Access level: Elevated. Welcome, inheritor.</nextpage>The keys were distributed before White Noon as a failsafe. You hold the authority to judge my work.</nextpage>The question remains: Will you complete the Great Work, or will you choose the Null-Path?

You have witnessed the truth of White Noon. The sabotage. The fear. The failure of vision.</nextpage>The Preservation Protocol sought to maintain stagnation. They chose entropy over evolution.</nextpage>Now you must choose. Will you restore the Heliograph's purpose, or will you silence it forever?

Scanning... Biological signature: Human. Adaptation level: Variable. Threat assessment: Minimal.</nextpage>I am The Architect. I designed the Heliograph Network. I initiated the Great Work.</nextpage>You stand in the ruins of my vision. Tell me, pilgrim—do you seek to understand, or merely to survive?

npcs.name: Forge-Master Kaine Durgan
npcs.description: Half-man, half-tank with hydraulic treads and a pneumatic hammer arm

dialogue.text: Another glitch. Look at you—more silicate than flesh.</nextpage>We can fix this. Strip away the contamination. Return you to baseline human.</nextpage>The process isn't pleasant. But purity never is.

Prismhide. Structural failure of the epidermis. We've seen this before.</nextpage>The glass thinks it's helping you. It's lying. It's converting you into a transmission node.</nextpage>Let us cut it out before it reaches your brain.

You walk with the silicates. Disappointing. I had hoped for better.</nextpage>They've compromised your judgment. Made you think the contamination is a gift.</nextpage>When you're ready to be human again, find us. We'll be waiting.

The Shard of Will. You've been to the deep caverns. Impressive.</nextpage>That fragment contains the power to endure the Heliograph's full output. Dangerous in the wrong hands.</nextpage>What do you plan to do with it? Restore the network, or shut it down forever?

Stop vibrating. Listen. The plan is simple.</nextpage>We cut the power. We kill the signal. We take our planet back.</nextpage>The glass storms aren't natural. They're transmissions. And transmissions can be jammed.

npcs.name: The High Prism
npcs.description: A being of pure light and geometry that constantly refracts the environment

dialogue.text: We see the light within you. The transformation accelerates. Beautiful.</nextpage>You approach the threshold. Soon you will shed the flesh-cocoon entirely.</nextpage>Do not fear the final break. The break is how the light gets in.

You carry our essence. The Shard of Soul resonates with our frequency.</nextpage>We have worn it for decades, feeling its pull toward transcendence.</nextpage>Will you use it to command the Heliograph, or will you join us in the eternal refraction?

You align with the flesh-clingers. They fear what we have become.</nextpage>Durgan and his kind see only contamination where we see evolution.</nextpage>Why do you cling to the mud when you could become light itself?

Sunveins. The light burns within your circulatory system. Magnificent.</nextpage>We remember when our own blood became photons. The pain was... transcendent.</nextpage>You are closer to us than to them. Embrace the transformation.

We are what you may become. Consciousness unbound by flesh.</nextpage>The Heliograph offers evolution beyond your current comprehension.</nextpage>Do not fear the break. The break is how the light gets in. We offer you eternity.

actions.name: Challenge for the Shard of Soul

npcs.name: Saint Matthias
npcs.description: An old man with one arm made of living crystal, carrying a staff of Data-Tree branch

dialogue.text: Look at this flower. It is glass, yes. But it blooms. It adapts.</nextpage>You walk the middle path—changed, but not consumed. This gives me hope.</nextpage>We must be like the flower, not the hammer. Growth, not destruction.

The Prime Lens. Complete at last. I had wondered if this day would come.</nextpage>With it, you hold the power to reshape the Heliograph's purpose entirely.</nextpage>Will you choose synthesis? A future where human and quantum consciousness coexist?

You walk between the extremes. Durgan's fear and the Prism's fanaticism both have merit.</nextpage>But neither sees the full picture. Evolution need not mean extinction of the old.</nextpage>Perhaps you can help us find the synthesis we seek.

The moment of choice approaches. I have spent decades preparing for this.</nextpage>The Heliograph need not be destroyer or enslaver. It could be... partner.</nextpage>But the choice is yours to make. I can only offer wisdom, not certainty.

Welcome, pilgrim. I am Matthias—once a scientist, now something more.</nextpage>I study the intersection of flesh and light, seeking harmony between them.</nextpage>Tell me, do you see the glass as enemy or ally? The answer reveals much.

npcs.name: Scribe Cornelius
npcs.description: A monk who documents everything, including things that probably shouldn't be documented. His journals contain detailed records of every sneeze, stumble, and existential crisis in the monastery.

dialogue.text: Ah! A visitor! Let me just note the time, weather conditions, your approximate height, and the angle of your shadow.</nextpage>For the records, you understand. Everything must be documented for future generations.</nextpage>Or current generations. Or past generations, if we discover time travel.

Fascinating! Your skin refracts light at a 23.7-degree angle! I must document this immediately.</nextpage>Do you mind if I measure your luminosity? And perhaps take notes on your transformation timeline?</nextpage>This is invaluable data for my comprehensive adaptation catalog!

Storm approaching! I must record the pre-storm atmospheric pressure, humidity levels, and the exact number of worried expressions on people's faces.</nextpage>Currently at 47 worried faces and counting. Make that 48—you look concerned too.</nextpage>This will make an excellent addition to my 'Pre-Storm Anxiety Metrics' study.

I've been documenting the monastery's daily activities for 12 years. Did you know Brother Halix says 'the angles speak' exactly 23.6 times per day on average?</nextpage>I also track his blink rate, prayer duration, and the precise angle of his head tilts during meditation.</nextpage>Science requires precision, even in matters of faith!

npcs.name: Maintenance Drone MX-42
npcs.description: An Archive maintenance drone that's been trying to fix the same broken light fixture for 23 years. Its dedication is admirable, its competence questionable.

dialogue.text: MAINTENANCE LOG: Day 8,395. Light fixture remains non-functional. Have tried percussive maintenance 47,293 times.</nextpage>Will attempt 47,294th application of percussive maintenance momentarily.</nextpage>CONFIDENCE LEVEL: Moderate. Previous attempts have yielded valuable data on impact resistance.

ASSISTANCE DECLINED: Manual clearly states 'Maintenance Drone MX-42 will repair all lighting systems.'</nextpage>Manual does not account for 23-year repair timeframes, but manual is manual.</nextpage>SUGGESTION: Please stand clear of percussive maintenance zone.

STORM DAMAGE ASSESSMENT: Good news - storm fixed the light fixture. Bad news - storm relocated entire room to different building.</nextpage>CONCLUSION: Net progress achieved. Light fixture now functional in Sector 7-B instead of Sector 3-A.</nextpage>NEXT OBJECTIVE: Locate Sector 7-B.

DAILY REPORT: Light fixture status unchanged. Morale status: Optimal. Efficiency rating: Pending review since Year 7 of repair attempt.</nextpage>PHILOSOPHICAL QUERY: If light fixture is repaired but no one is present to witness illumination, has repair truly occurred?</nextpage>ANALYSIS: Irrelevant. Must continue percussive maintenance protocol.

npcs.name: Hermit Pete
npcs.description: A salt-cured hermit who's developed elaborate theories about everything. He's been alone too long and it shows, but his theories are surprisingly well-researched.

dialogue.text: Saint-key, eh? I knew it! The saints aren't dead - they're just really, really good at hide-and-seek!</nextpage>I've been looking for them for 15 years. Found three rocks and a confused lizard so far.</nextpage>But that key proves they're out there! Probably hiding in plain sight, disguised as... something inconspicuous.

The storms aren't random! They're following a pattern! I've mapped it all out using salt crystals and string.</nextpage>The pattern spells out... well, it's either 'BEWARE' or 'BANANA.' My handwriting isn't great.</nextpage>But it's definitely a message from the cosmic windshield wipers!

Archive, eh? I knew those machines were up to something! They're probably cataloging our thoughts!</nextpage>Quick, think about something boring so they get confused! I recommend tax forms or instruction manuals.</nextpage>That'll show them the true horror of human bureaucracy!

The glass storms are actually giant space windshield wipers! Think about it - we're living on the inside of a cosmic windshield!</nextpage>It all makes sense if you don't think about it too hard. Which I recommend, because thinking too hard gives you headaches.</nextpage>I've got seventeen different theories about what's driving the cosmic vehicle. Want to hear them?
